sections.In the books:
In the ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' novels, Gilly's child actually does not possess a name. 
<!--I comment the following cotents out for they seem to be of little relationship with the topic of this article - Greeneese at August 11, 2014 : The inhabitants of the [[Seven Kingdoms]] south of [[the Wall]] are named in a ceremony on the same day they are born, which becomes known as a "[[nameday]]". A "nameday" is functionally equivalent to a "birthday", hence the phrase "naked as my nameday", it is just a quirk of their culture that the act of naming, not the birth itself, is what is signified.However, -->
Due to the harsh conditions [[Beyond the Wall]], the [[Free Folk|wildlings]] have a high infant mortality rate and believe naming a baby after birth is an ill-omen. Therefore, they do not give their babies names at all until they have survived to fully two years of age. Gilly follows that custom, and for that reason she has not given any name to her baby yet. Wildlings do sometimes give their babies nicknames in the meantime, but Gilly hasn't called her baby "Sam" in the books.

Some people in Castle Black call the baby "Monster" affectionately, while others call him "Abomination" because he is born of incest.
